Each number each edition contains eight pages of seven long columns each, making fifty-six. umns in all. It is always printed on good paper and in clear type — making it the idsomest and most legible Newspaper in the United States. The Times aims, first of all, to give the earliest and most reliable NEWS from all tions of the United States and from all parts of the World. Its Correspond- oe, Foreign and Domestic, in variety, fullness and literary interest and ability, lot surpassed by that of any other journal. In the Southern States especially, a which it has been so difficult to obtain reliable information, the Times has a large ber of able, intelligent and candid correspondents whose reports of incidents and ion are of great interest and value ; — and from every Capital in Europe it receives y and reliable intelligence. i its Editorial Department the Times seeks to criticise passing events of every with candor, intelligence and a paramount regard for the best interests of the nunity. It avoids always appeals to mere passion, and aims to direct and con- the judgment rather than appeal to prejudice. In politics it maintains the .mental principles of the Union Party — seeking the Restoration of Peace and on upon the basis of Equal Rights and universal justice, and urging always a* rywhere the elevation and improvement of all classes of the community. In dt with the South it will insist upon a just and considerate policy — demanding f steady obedience to the Constitution and laws of the Union, ample protection t enfranchised slaves in all their rights of life, liberty and property— the devel- „nt of the material resources of the country, and the general advancement of all ises of the people in education, morality and religion. All topics, in all depart- its, foreign and domestic, will receive in the Times full and careful discussion. n Literary criticism and intelligence, the Times will be especially full ani^ plete.
